summary: This document is an email chain between a prosecutor's office and Jeffrey Goldberg, Amazon's Associate General Counsel, discussing a subpoena (CRIM1031692) issued to Amazon for records related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The correspondence focuses on Amazon's legal position regarding First Amendment protections for customer purchase records and the implications of Epstein's death on the subpoena's validity.

persons.name: Jeffrey Goldberg
persons.role: Associate General Counsel, Litigation & Regulatory at Amazon.com Inc.
persons.context: Amazon's legal representative corresponding with prosecutors regarding a subpoena for records related to the Epstein investigation, citing First Amendment case law to argue for a heightened legal standard.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Epstein' and the deceased subject of the investigation for which Amazon records are being subpoenaed. His death raises questions about the continuing need for the records.

connections.description: Goldberg, as Amazon's counsel, is responding to a government subpoena seeking records related to Epstein, indicating a legal/procedural connection between the company and the investigation's subject.

events.title: Email discussion on subpoena legal standards
events.description: Email exchange where Amazon's counsel provides legal authorities and raises questions about the subpoena's validity post-Epstein's death and regarding First Amendment concerns.

events.title: Prosecutor transition due to trial
events.description: A prosecutor informs Goldberg that a colleague will take over the subpoena matter due to an upcoming trial, and reiterates the issues of overbreadth and the need for account/shipping records for specific addresses.

locations: Seattle, WA 98121 (Amazon.com Inc. office address: 2021 7th Avenue)
Addresses listed in the subpoena (unspecified, but referenced as the subject of the records request)
keyFacts: A subpoena (CRIM1031692) was issued to Amazon.com as part of the criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.

Amazon's legal counsel, Jeffrey Goldberg, cited First Amendment case law arguing for a heightened standard of relevance and need before compelling production of customer 'expressive materials' like bookstore or library records.
The death of Jeffrey Epstein raised a specific legal question from prosecutors about whether the concerns over the subpoena 'continue after Epstein's death'.

The subpoena requested records for accounts associated with specific addresses, which Amazon initially considered overbroad; prosecutors sought to narrow the request to account information and records of items shipped to those addresses.
Amazon indicated it was preserving responsive information and might file a motion to quash the subpoena if the government pursued the request for expressive materials.
